title: Lesson 14: Eigenvectors and Eigenvalues
objectives: Find eigenvalues using the characteristic polynomial

cards.back:
A non-zero vector that stays on its own span (line through origin) when transformed.

It only gets stretched, squished, or flipped - never rotated off its line.

The scalar factor \( \lambda \) by which an eigenvector is stretched or squished during the transformation.

If \( \vec{v} \) is an eigenvector: \( A\vec{v} = \lambda\vec{v} \)

cards.front: What is the defining equation for eigenvectors and eigenvalues?
cards.back:
\( A\vec{v} = \lambda\vec{v} \)

The matrix \( A \) acting on eigenvector \( \vec{v} \) gives the same result as simply scaling \( \vec{v} \) by \( \lambda \).

Solve: \( \det(A - \lambda I) = 0 \)

This is called the characteristic equation. Its solutions are the eigenvalues.

cards.front: What do different eigenvalue values mean geometrically?
cards.back:
\( \lambda > 1 \): eigenvector stretched

\( 0 < \lambda < 1 \): eigenvector squished

\( \lambda < 0 \): eigenvector flipped and scaled

\( \lambda = 1 \): eigenvector unchanged

\( \lambda = 0 \): eigenvector squished to origin

cards.front: For a 3D rotation, what is special about the eigenvalue 1?
cards.back:
The eigenvector with eigenvalue 1 is the axis of rotation.

It's the only direction that doesn't move during the rotation.

A basis consisting entirely of eigenvectors.

In this basis, the transformation matrix becomes diagonal, with eigenvalues on the diagonal. This greatly simplifies calculations like matrix powers.

cards.front: Can every matrix be diagonalized (have an eigenbasis)?
cards.back:
No. A matrix can be diagonalized only if it has enough linearly independent eigenvectors to form a basis.

Some matrices (like shears) don't have enough eigenvectors.
